keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including CBP and ICE, are under judicial scrutiny for allegedly violating a judge’s order to avoid tear gas and less-lethal munitions during protests in Chicago.
US District Judge Sara Ellis issued a sweeping order restricting the use of force, crowd control tactics, and actions against journalists during protests, requiring body-worn cameras to be used.
The Trump administration defended its actions, denying reports of tear gas use without warning, while acknowledging the absence of personal observation of such incidents.
Judge Ellis expressed concern that her order may not be being followed, citing reports of tear gas deployment and lack of warnings before use.
Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE deployment in Chicagoland from September 8 to October 3, led to over 1,000 arrests and intensified public and judicial scrutiny.
Protests at the Broadview ICE facility continued into October, with over 100 demonstrators gathered and at least 15 arrests made in each of two recent demonstrations.
The judge has ordered that body-worn cameras be used by all CBP agents in Chicago, though exceptions exist for undercover or non-uniformed agents.

Officials such as Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers testified, but the judge requested further testimony from Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino due to their leadership roles during the protests.

namedEntities.name: Judge Sara Ellis
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US District Judge in Chicago, Obama appointee, issued a judicial order restricting ICE and CBP actions during protests and requiring body-worn cameras.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central legal authority overseeing enforcement actions in Chicago and has issued specific orders requiring restraint in the use of force and transparency in protest response, making her central to the conflict between federal agencies and civil liberties.

namedEntities.name: Operation Midway Blitz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Trump administration ICE deployment targeting migrants across Chicagoland, resulting in over 1,000 arrests between September 8 and October 3, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the catalyst for the judicial review and public scrutiny, as it directly led to protests and raised concerns about the use of force and transparency in enforcement actions.

namedEntities.name: Customs and Border Protection (CBP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency under U.S. Customs and Border Protection, responsible for immigration enforcement and border control.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CBP agents were at the center of the judicial scrutiny for alleged violations of Judge Ellis’s orders, including unauthorized use of tear gas and lack of body-worn camera use.

namedEntities.name: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency under DHS that enforces immigration laws and conducts large-scale arrests.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ICE was directly involved in Operation Midway Blitz and is under judicial review for its use of force and crowd control tactics during protests.

namedEntities.name: Russell Hott
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Interim head of Chicago’s ICE field office, who left the city to return to Washington, DC.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was initially required to appear before Judge Ellis to explain the use of tear gas and lack of warnings, but departed before testimony; his absence raises questions about accountability and leadership.

namedEntities.name: Gregory Bovino
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief patrol agent at CBP, whose testimony is being scheduled for later depositions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As a senior CBP official, he is being requested to testify because of his role in on-the-ground operations during protests, directly linking him to enforcement actions.

namedEntities.name: Kyle Harvick
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Deputy Incident Commander at CBP, testified during the hearing about compliance with camera use and response protocols.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was the primary official presented by federal officials to explain actions during protests, though the judge expressed concerns about transparency and compliance.

namedEntities.name: Shawn Byers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: ICE Deputy Field Office Director, testified about incidents at the Broadview facility and stated no disciplinary actions were taken.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represented ICE’s position on protest incidents and response, though the judge remains skeptical about full compliance with her orders.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It has become the focal point of anti-ICE protests, with repeated demonstrations and arrests, prompting both public and judicial scrutiny of enforcement tactics.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, US District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order restricting federal immigration enforcement tactics in Chicago, requiring all CBP agents to wear body-worn cameras and prohibiting the use of tear gas and less-lethal munitions without warning. The order was challenged by the Trump administration, which defended its actions during Operation Midway Blitz—a large-scale ICE deployment in Chicagoland from September 8 to October 3 that resulted in over 1,000 arrests. Federal officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified that tear gas was not used without warning, though the judge expressed serious concerns about compliance, citing media reports of such use. Initially, ICE interim head Russell Hott was required to testify but left the city; the judge has now ordered his deposition, along with CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino, to ensure full accountability. Protests at the Broadview ICE facility continued, with over 100 demonstrators and multiple arrests, highlighting public resistance to immigration enforcement. Judge Ellis remains adamant that her orders are being followed, stating she is deeply concerned about the lack of transparency and accountability in federal enforcement actions.
title: Federal Officials Try to Reassure Judge They’re Following Her Orders to Tone Down and Record Chicagoland Protest Actions
